publicNetworkWarning.title: Public Network Warning
publicNetworkWarning.message: Public networks increase risk of deception (rogue hotspots, fake portals). Encryption reduces some risks, but judgment still matters. Don't enter sensitive credentials on untrusted networks or pages.

networkContext.title: What to know
networkContext.home: Your home network is typically secure—you control the router and who connects. Still, always check for HTTPS (the padlock icon) when entering passwords or payment info. Most modern sites do this automatically.
networkContext.coffeeShop: Coffee shop Wi-Fi is a prime target for attackers. Anyone nearby can set up a fake hotspot with the same name. Always use HTTPS, avoid entering sensitive data, and consider a VPN for extra protection.
networkContext.airport: Airport networks are high-risk environments. Thousands of travelers, many fake hotspots, and attackers know people are in a hurry. Treat any airport Wi-Fi as hostile—VPN is strongly recommended for any sensitive activity.
networkContext.hotel: Hotel Wi-Fi is shared with many guests and often has weak security. The network operator can see unencrypted traffic. Use HTTPS for everything and consider VPN if accessing sensitive accounts.

vpnActive.message: VPN shifts trust from the local network to the VPN provider. It doesn't make you invincible—choose a reputable provider and remember that the VPN can see your traffic.
vpnActive.dnsLeakNote: Note: DNS requests can sometimes leak outside the VPN depending on settings.

wireView.title: Wire View
wireView.subtitle: What the network can observe
wireView.readyToObserveHint: Click "Send Request" to see what network observers could see when you submit the login form.

passive.secure: What an observer sees: encrypted content, visible destination
passive.plain: What an observer sees: your actual data

rogueHotspot.secure: What an observer sees: encrypted content, visible destination
rogueHotspot.plain: What an observer sees: your actual data (plus higher interception risk)

compromisedEndpoint.secure: What an observer sees: encrypted content, but the device is already compromised
compromisedEndpoint.plain: What an observer sees: your actual data (device compromised)

wireView.whatObserverSeesSecure: What an observer sees: encrypted gibberish
wireView.whatObserverSeesPlain: What an observer sees: your actual data

passive.secure: HTTPS protects the content from passive observers, but they still learn which site you visit.
passive.plain: With HTTP, anyone on the network can read your data directly.

rogueHotspot.secure: HTTPS protects the content, but rogue hotspots can still trick you with fake portals or phishing pages.
rogueHotspot.plain: On a rogue hotspot, plain-text HTTP data is easy to intercept.

compromisedEndpoint.secure: If your device is infected, HTTPS can’t protect what malware reads before encryption.
compromisedEndpoint.plain: A compromised device exposes your data regardless of HTTP or HTTPS.

explainSecure.title: Why can't they read this?
explainSecure.body: HTTPS encrypts your data before sending it. Think of putting your letter in a tamper-proof lock box—only the recipient has the key. The hex codes above are what an attacker would capture: meaningless scrambled data that modern computers cannot crack. They can see which website you're visiting (the address on the box), but not what you're saying inside.

explainPlain.title: Why is this dangerous?
explainPlain.body: HTTP sends your data as plain text—like writing your password on a postcard. Anyone on the same network (coffee shop Wi-Fi, hotel, airport) can intercept and read everything you send. Your username and password are completely exposed.

metadata.title: Metadata
metadata.metadataNote: Even with HTTPS encryption, the network can see which website you connected to—just not what you sent or received.
metadata.advancedSkip: If this is too much, feel free to skip it. The core lesson still stands.
advancedItems: DNS lookups can reveal the domain you are trying to reach.
SNI can expose the site name during the TLS handshake; ECH can hide it, but it is not widely deployed yet.
DoH/DoT can reduce DNS visibility, but they are not universal and can be blocked or misconfigured.

handshake.title: TLS Handshake
handshake.step1: Client Hello: supported cipher suites, random bytes
handshake.step2: Server Hello: chosen cipher, server certificate
handshake.observersNote: Observers can see this handshake occurred but cannot derive the session keys.
handshake.tooltip: The handshake process is visible to observers—they can see a secure connection is being established—but the encryption keys remain secret.

request.title: Request
request.encryptedNote: Network observers see encrypted data, not the actual content.
request.ciphertextDisclaimer: Note: Ciphertext shown is illustrative, not an actual TLS dump.
request.plainTextWarning: Anyone on the network can read your credentials!
request.tooltip: The HTTP request contains the data your browser sends to the server, including headers and body content.
request.tooltipEncrypted: The payload (request body) is encrypted and unreadable to network observers.
request.tooltipPlainText: The payload is sent as plain text—anyone on the network can read it.

response.title: Response
response.sessionWarning: Session tokens are also visible! An attacker could hijack your session.
response.tooltip: The HTTP response contains data the server sends back, including headers (like cookies) and body content.
response.tooltipEncrypted: The response is encrypted—only your browser can decrypt it.
response.tooltipPlainText: The response is in plain text—anyone on the network can read it, including session tokens.

summary.protectedMessage: Even on public Wi-Fi, encryption scrambled your credentials into unreadable code. An attacker would only see the gibberish above. Always look for the padlock (lock icon) in your browser's address bar before entering passwords or payment information.
summary.exposedMessage: Your username and password traveled across the network as readable text. On public Wi-Fi (coffee shops, airports, hotels), anyone with simple tools could have captured everything. This is why modern websites always use HTTPS.

timeline.connectTooltipVpn: Your device first connects to the VPN server through an encrypted tunnel, then the VPN connects to the destination.
timeline.connectTooltipDirect: DNS resolves domain name to IP address, then TCP establishes a connection to the server.
timeline.handshakeTooltip: Client and server exchange certificates and agree on encryption keys. This happens before any data is sent. An observer sees this handshake occur but cannot read the encrypted content.
timeline.requestTooltipSecure: Your login credentials are encrypted before being sent. Observers see encrypted data.
timeline.requestTooltipInsecure: Your login credentials are sent in plain text. Anyone on the network can read them.
timeline.responseTooltipSecure: The server's response is encrypted. Only you can decrypt and read it.
timeline.responseTooltipInsecure: The server's response is in plain text. Anyone on the network can read it.

metadata.passive: Metadata (like destination and connection type) stays visible to passive observers.
metadata.rogueHotspot: Rogue hotspots still see metadata and can attempt deception even when content is encrypted.
metadata.compromisedEndpoint: If the device is compromised, metadata visibility is the least of the problem.

handshake.passive: The handshake is visible, but the keys are not.
handshake.rogueHotspot: If you see certificate warnings, stop—this may be a MITM attempt.
handshake.compromisedEndpoint: A compromised device can be manipulated even if the handshake is valid.

passive.secure: Request content is encrypted; only metadata leaks.
passive.plain: Request content is readable to anyone on the network.

rogueHotspot.secure: Content is encrypted, but you can still be tricked by fake login pages.
rogueHotspot.plain: Plain-text requests are trivial to intercept on rogue hotspots.

compromisedEndpoint.secure: Malware can read the request before encryption.
compromisedEndpoint.plain: Compromise exposes content regardless of protocol.

passive.secure: Encrypted responses keep content hidden from passive observers.
passive.plain: Plain-text responses can expose session tokens.

rogueHotspot.secure: Encrypted responses stay private, but phishing risk remains.
rogueHotspot.plain: Plain-text responses are easy to capture on rogue hotspots.

compromisedEndpoint.secure: Compromised devices can read responses after decryption.
compromisedEndpoint.plain: Compromise exposes responses regardless of protocol.

quiz.title: Security Knowledge Quiz
quiz.description: Test your understanding of network security concepts
quiz.question: Question

q1.question: When you connect to a website using HTTP, who can see your password?
options: Only the website you're connecting to
Anyone on the same network
Only your internet service provider
Nobody can see it
q1.explanation: With HTTP, data is transmitted in plain text. Anyone on the same network (like a coffee shop Wi-Fi) can intercept and read your password using simple tools.

q2.question: What does the 'S' in HTTPS stand for?
options: Speed
Secure
Server
Standard
q2.explanation: HTTPS stands for HyperText Transfer Protocol Secure. The 'S' indicates that the connection uses encryption (TLS) to protect data in transit.

q3.question: Which of the following can a VPN hide from your local network?
options: Only your passwords
Only the websites you visit
Both your passwords and the websites you visit
Neither - VPNs don't hide anything
q3.explanation: A VPN creates an encrypted tunnel for ALL your traffic. This hides both the content (passwords, data) and metadata (which websites you visit) from local observers.

q4.question: You're at a coffee shop and need to check your bank account. What should you do?
options: Connect to the free Wi-Fi and log in normally
Make sure the bank website uses HTTPS, or use cellular data
Ask the barista for the Wi-Fi password first
Use an incognito/private browser window
q4.explanation: For sensitive activities like banking, ensure the site uses HTTPS (look for the lock icon). Better yet, use your phone's cellular data instead of public Wi-Fi. Incognito mode doesn't protect network traffic.

q5.question: When using HTTPS, what can your ISP still see?
options: Your passwords and form data
The content of emails you send
Which websites you visit (but not the specific pages or content)
Everything you do online
q5.explanation: HTTPS encrypts the content of your communication, but your ISP can still see which domains (websites) you connect to. This is called 'metadata'. To hide this, you would need a VPN.

q6.question: What's the main risk of a 'fake hotspot' attack?
options: Slow internet speeds
An attacker can see all your unencrypted traffic
Your phone battery drains faster
You get charged for Wi-Fi usage
q6.explanation: In a fake hotspot (evil twin) attack, an attacker creates a network that mimics a legitimate one. All your traffic passes through their equipment, allowing them to intercept unencrypted data.

q7.question: Which statement about VPNs is TRUE?
options: VPNs make you completely anonymous online
VPNs slow down your internet but hide your traffic from local observers
VPNs only work with HTTPS websites
VPNs prevent all types of cyber attacks
q7.explanation: VPNs add a layer of encryption that may slightly slow your connection, but they effectively hide your traffic from your local network and ISP. However, the VPN provider can still see your traffic, and VPNs don't prevent phishing or malware.

q8.question: What information is always visible even when using HTTPS?
options: Your username and password
The domain name you're connecting to
Your credit card number
The content of your messages
q8.explanation: Even with HTTPS, the domain name (like 'example.com') is visible because DNS queries are typically unencrypted, and the TLS handshake reveals the server name. This is why VPNs are useful for hiding which sites you visit.

practice.title: Micro-practice

step1.prompt: You're on your home Wi-Fi. What should you prioritize first?
options: Use HTTPS sites and keep the router updated.
Assume the router is hostile and use a VPN for everything.
Stop and clean the device before logging in.

rationale.passive: With a {model} attacker, HTTPS protects content while router updates reduce easy compromises.
rationale.rogueHotspot: Even with a {model} attacker, HTTPS and router hygiene still reduce risk at home.
rationale.compromisedEndpoint: With a {model} attacker, the device itself is the risk. Clean it before logging in.

step2.prompt: A family member asks for the Wi-Fi password. What is the safest response?
options: Share it, but keep a strong WPA2/WPA3 password and update it if needed.
Post it publicly for convenience.
Ignore device security because HTTPS is enough.

rationale.passive: A strong Wi-Fi password limits who can observe traffic on the local network.
rationale.rogueHotspot: Strong Wi-Fi security reduces the chance of unauthorized access or spoofed access points.
rationale.compromisedEndpoint: Even with device risks, controlling who joins the network still matters.

step1.prompt: You're at a coffee shop. What is the safest first step?
options: Use HTTPS only and avoid sensitive logins.
Verify the network name with staff and consider a VPN.
Assume the device is compromised and stop before logging in.

rationale.passive: With a {model} attacker, HTTPS and avoiding sensitive logins reduce exposure.
rationale.rogueHotspot: With a {model} attacker, verifying the hotspot and using a VPN helps prevent interception.
rationale.compromisedEndpoint: With a {model} attacker, network choices do not protect you; fix the device first.

step2.prompt: You need to check email. What is the safest choice?
options: Proceed only if the site is HTTPS and there are no certificate warnings.
Use HTTP because it loads faster.
Wait until you can use a trusted device or network.

rationale.passive: HTTPS prevents a {model} attacker from reading content.
rationale.rogueHotspot: A {model} attacker relies on downgrades or fake certificates, so only proceed if HTTPS is intact.
rationale.compromisedEndpoint: If the device is compromised, postpone until you can use a trusted device.

step1.prompt: At airport Wi-Fi, what is the safest first step?
options: Use a VPN plus HTTPS for sensitive tasks.
Skip VPN because HTTPS is always enough.
Stop and clean the device before logging in.

rationale.passive: A {model} attacker still sees metadata; a VPN reduces local visibility.
rationale.rogueHotspot: With a {model} attacker, VPN plus HTTPS adds protection against interception.
rationale.compromisedEndpoint: If the device is compromised, network protections cannot help.

step2.prompt: A captive portal asks for credentials. What should you do?
options: Enter your email password to unlock Wi-Fi.
Use the portal only for access and avoid real account passwords.
Assume the device is compromised and do not proceed.

rationale.passive: Even with a {model} attacker, never enter real credentials into a portal.
rationale.rogueHotspot: A {model} attacker can use fake portals; avoid real credentials and verify the domain.
rationale.compromisedEndpoint: If the device is compromised, avoid logging in at all.

step1.prompt: At the hotel network, what is the safest first step?
options: Confirm the network with reception and use HTTPS.
Assume it is safe like home.
Stop and clean the device before logging in.

rationale.passive: A {model} attacker can still observe metadata; verifying the network and HTTPS are safer.
rationale.rogueHotspot: With a {model} attacker, verifying the network reduces the chance of a fake hotspot.
rationale.compromisedEndpoint: If the device is compromised, network choices are secondary to cleaning it.

step2.prompt: You need to access banking. What is the safest choice?
options: Use a VPN and verify HTTPS before logging in.
Use HTTP for speed.
Wait until you can use a trusted device or network.

rationale.passive: A {model} attacker cannot read HTTPS content, and a VPN reduces local exposure.
rationale.rogueHotspot: With a {model} attacker, VPN plus HTTPS reduces interception risk.
rationale.compromisedEndpoint: If the device is compromised, do not log in until it is cleaned.

attackerModelNotes.passive: Assume someone is quietly observing traffic. HTTPS hides content but not the destination.
attackerModelNotes.rogueHotspot: Assume a fake hotspot could try to trick you even if HTTPS is used.
attackerModelNotes.compromisedEndpoint: Assume the device is infected. Network encryption won’t protect what malware can read.

introduction.title: Welcome to The Glass Wall
content: You've probably heard "use HTTPS" — but do you really know why?
Most people don't. And that's okay. In the next few minutes, you'll see what happens when your data travels across a network — and why encryption matters.
We call this "The Glass Wall" because without protection, the barrier between your private data and anyone watching is as thin as glass. You just can't see it.

userView.title: What You See
content: This is a familiar sight — a login page. You type your credentials, click submit, and trust that it works.
But here's what most people don't think about: your data doesn't teleport to the server. It travels through wires, routers, and wireless signals. And on that journey, someone might be watching.

wireView.title: What the Network Sees
content: This is the other side of the glass — what's visible to anyone observing your network traffic.
On an unprotected network, this could be the person at the next table in a coffee shop, or software silently monitoring the network.
Think of it like a one-way mirror: you can't see who's watching, but they can see everything you send.

protocolToggle.title: The Critical Choice
content: HTTP sends your data as plain text — readable by anyone observing the network.
HTTPS encrypts your data before it leaves your device. To observers, your passwords and personal information become unreadable scrambled characters.
Toggle between these modes and watch what appears in the Wire View.

vpnToggle.title: An Extra Shield
content: A VPN creates an encrypted tunnel for ALL your traffic — not just one website.
It hides which websites you visit from anyone on the local network. Useful in coffee shops, airports, and hotels.
But here's the nuance: a VPN shifts trust to the VPN provider. It doesn't make you invisible. Choose wisely.

actionArea.title: Watch Your Data Travel
content: When you click "Send Request," you'll watch your data travel from your browser to the server — step by step.
Pay close attention to what appears in the Wire View. With HTTP, you'll see your password in plain text. With HTTPS, you'll see encrypted gibberish.

scenarioSelector.title: Context Matters
content: Not all networks are equal in risk.
Your home Wi-Fi is different from airport Wi-Fi. A corporate network has different protections than a coffee shop.
Try different scenarios to understand how your environment affects your risk level. Awareness is the first step to safe behavior.

learningTools.title: Deepen Your Understanding
content: Use these tools to reinforce what you learn:
Cheat Sheet — A printable reference guide. Compare — See HTTP and HTTPS side-by-side. Quiz — Test your knowledge.
Come back to these after you've experimented with the main visualization.

progressTracker.title: Track Your Exploration
content: This tracks which combinations you've tried — HTTP, HTTPS, with and without VPN.
Try all four combinations to fully understand how each layer of protection changes what's visible on the network.

ready.title: You're Ready
content: Try this: Make sure HTTP is selected (no encryption), then click "Send Request" and watch what appears in the Wire View — notice your password is visible.
Then switch to HTTPS and send again. See the difference.
